discussion.content: C. In interface configuration mode, the IPv6 OSPF process area ID combination assigns interfaces to OSPFv3 areas.

questions.answer_ET: D. In router configuration mode, the IPv6 OSPF interface area ID combination assigns interfaces to OSPFv3 areas.

choices.A: In interface configuration mode, the OSPFv3 area ID combination assigns interfaces to OSPFv3 areas.
choices.B: In router configuration mode, the network wildcard area ID combination assigns networks to OSPFv3 areas.
choices.C: In interface configuration mode, the IPv6 OSPF process area ID combination assigns interfaces to OSPFv3 areas.

questions.question_text: When implementing OSPFv3, which statement describes the configuration of OSPF areas?
questions.answer: D. In router configuration mode, the IPv6 OSPF interface area ID combination assigns interfaces to OSPFv3 areas.

discussion.content: A. The OSPF areas are not configured correctly.

questions.answer_ET: E. There is not enough information to make a determination.

choices.D: The 172.16.x.x networks are discontiguous. OSPF is automatically summarizing them to 172.16.0.0/16 and data is being "black holed."
choices.B: The wildcard masks for the 10.x.x.x networks are incorrect.
choices.C: The 172.16.x.x networks need to be connected to area 0 using virtual links.
choices.A: The OSPF areas are not configured correctly.

questions.answer: E. There is not enough information to make a determination.
questions.question_text:
RouterA#
~~~~~
!
router ospf 1
log-adjacency-changes
network 10.0.0.0 0.255.255.255 area 1
network 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 1
!
~~~~~
RouterB#
~~~~~
router ospf 1
log-adjacency-changes
network 10.0.0.0 0.255.255.255 area 2
network 172.16.2.0 0.0.0.255 area 2
!
~~~~~
RouterC#
~~~~~
!
router ospf 1
log-adjacency-changes
network 10.0.0.0 0.255.255.255 area 0
!
~~~~~
Refer to the exhibits. You are verifying your OSPF implementation, and it does not seem to be functioning properly. What can you conclude from the exhibit and the show running- configuration command output?
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Explanation -
The E0/0 & E0/1 interfaces of router C belong to area 0 while E0/0 of router A belongs to area 1; E0/0 of router B belongs to area 2 -> it is not correct. Both E0/0 interfaces of router A & B should be in area 0 -> A is not correct.

questions.answer_ET: D. Router A does not have any reachable OSPF neighbors.
questions.answer_description:
Explanation -
The 224.0.0.5 address is the multicast for OSPF routers. Therefore when you ping to this address all OSPF routers will reply but from the output we learn that only the local router responded -> Router A does not have any reachable OSPF neighbors.

choices.B: None of the router A interfaces are participating in the OSPF routing process.
choices.A: Only the router A loopback interface is participating in the OSPF routing process.
choices.C: Router A is using the loopback interface IP address as its OSPF router ID.

discussion.content: D. Router A does not have any reachable OSPF neighbors.
A. Only the router A loopback interface is participating in the OSPF routing process.

questions.answer: D. Router A does not have any reachable OSPF neighbors.
questions.question_text:
OSPF is enabled on router A. You execute the following command on router A and receive the accompanying output:

RouterA#ping 224.0.0.5 repeat 1 -
Type escape sequence to abort.
Sending 1, 100-byte ICMP Echos to 224.0.0.5, timeout is 2 seconds:
Reply to request 0 from 10.100.100.1, 4 ms
10.100.100.1 is the IP address of a loopback interface on router A.
What can you conclude about router A?

questions.answer_ET: D. The router will be an ABR with s1/0 in area 0, f0/0 in area 1, and f0/1 in area 2.

choices.A: All interfaces will be in area 0.
choices.B: The router will be an ABR with s1/0 in area 0 and f0/0 and 0/1 in area 1.
choices.C: The router will be an ABR with s1/0 in area 0 and f0/0 and 0/1 in area 2.

questions.answer: D. The router will be an ABR with s1/0 in area 0, f0/0 in area 1, and f0/1 in area 2.

discussion.content: D. The router will be an ABR with s1/0 in area 0, f0/0 in area 1, and f0/1 in area 2.

choices.B: Data packets are process switches for this mapping entry.
choices.D: The mapping entry was created in response to an NHRP registration request.
choices.C: NHRP mapping is for networks that are local to this router.
choices.A: It was obtained directly from the next-hop server.

questions.answer_ET: E. The NHRP mapping entry cannot be overwritten.
questions.answer_description:
Show NHRP: Examples -
The following is sample output from the show ipnhrp command:

Router# show ipnhrp -
10.0.0.2 255.255.255.255, tunnel 100 created 0:00:43 expire 1:59:16 Type: dynamic Flags: authoritative
NBMA address: 10.1111.1111.1111.1111.1111.1111.1111.1111.1111.11 10.0.0.1 255.255.255.255, Tunnel0 created 0:10:03 expire 1:49:56 Type: static Flags: authoritative

NBMA address: 10.1.1.2 -
The fields in the sample display are as follows:

The IP address and its network mask in the IP-to-NBMA address cache. The mask is always 255.255.255.255 because Cisco does not support aggregation of
NBMA information through NHRP.

The interface type and number and how long ago it was created (hours:minutes:seconds).

The time in which the positive and negative authoritative NBMA address will expire (hours:minutes:seconds). This value is based on the ipnhrpholdtime command.

Type of interface:
dynamic--NBMA address was obtained from the NHRP Request packet. static--NBMA address was statically configured.

Flags:
authoritative--Indicates that the NHRP information was obtained from the Next Hop Server or router that maintains the NBMA-to-IP address mapping for a particular destination.
Reference:
http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/12_4/ip_addr/configuration/guide/hadnhrp.html
questions.answer: E. The NHRP mapping entry cannot be overwritten.

discussion.content: A. It was obtained directly from the next-hop server.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the following output:

Router#showipnhrp detail -
10.1.1.2/8 via 10.2.1.2, Tunnel1 created 00:00:12, expire 01:59:47 TypE.dynamic, Flags: authoritative unique nat registered used NBMA address: 10.12.1.2
What does the authoritative flag mean in regards to the NHRP information?
